subject: Add sensor instance id command line argument.
commitMessage:
Add sensor instance id command line argument.

Introduce `-i|--sensor-id` flag to explicitly set sensor
suffix for dbus name.

Sample usage:

   phosphor-hwmon-readd -i test_sensor_id -o /apb/...

Will register the service with the following busname:

   xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon-test_sensor_id.Hwmon1

This change required as a part of privilege separation work:
  https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/issues/3383

Signed-off-by: Anton D. Kachalov <gmouse@google.com>
Change-Id: I48ff9c3efe0edb84718ff8f695e7e932af5445de

Patch Set 6:

This change has been tested with witherspoon target under qemu:

```
# ps|grep readd
...  phosphor-hwmon-readd -i 5bac525f4814fa5b23de2ca72c2219a05df5dae3cdcf9c2a1a89e5b4585acf47 -o /ahb/apb/bus@1e78a000/i2c-bus@380/tmp275@4a
```

The failed hwmon is for max31785. The readd daemon was unable to locate corresponding hwmon instance.

Patch Set 6:

Could you break these up into two commits, one to change the busname, and one to move the unit/udev files into the repo?

nit: spelling
Done
could you toss an example into here?
Done
does this belong in the other commit?
Done
Since you're going to put this in the environment file, there isn't any need to pass it in.  The code can just directly call getEnv like it does all of the other env vars in that file.

I'm not passion about magic environment variables. This override argument is optional. If not specified, then the sensor id will be generated as a std::hash as it works now.
I would prefer explicit argument that will be clearly state sensor id in "ps" output.
This whole application is driven by environment variables.  That being said, I'm open to what the other reviewers think.
Did I miss how the HW_SENSOR_ID is being provided to this service file in this commit?
that's a good point.  Was the intent instead to put it into the config file, in which case it should be read by the code with a getenv?
There is unsubmitted change to openbmc/openbmc repo that generates HW_SENSOR_ID variable and append it to the /etc/default/obmc/hwmon/* stuff if it is not already set over there.
Done
Where does this end up coming from?  I don't see it in this or the parent commit.

It comes from:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/40359/3/meta-phosphor/classes/obmc-phosphor-image.bbclass line 116.
In that case, it seems like an environment would be more appropriate, no?  Otherwise this code doesn't do the sane thing without a co-req'd change over in the recipe.

If variable is not set, that's a clear misconfiguration and makes the running service inaccessible for the callees because they will be refused due to missing busconfig ACLs that are generated by postprocess script: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/40359/3/meta-phosphor/classes/obmc-phosphor-image.bbclass

Even if the variable is empty, the empty value of ${HW_SENSOR_ID} for ExecStart will be translated into an empty argument, that falls into default behavior: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-hwmon/+/40214/10/mainloop.cpp line 376.

```
execve("/usr/bin/phosphor-hwmon-readd", ["phosphor-hwmon-readd", "-i", "", "-o", "/ahb/apb/bus@1e78a000/i2c-bus@c0"...], 0x7ead0dc0 /* 10 vars */) = 0
```

> If variable is not set, that's a clear misconfiguration and makes the running service inaccessible for the callees because they will be refused due to missing busconfig ACLs that are generated by postprocess script

Yes, but that requires this script to also be merged at the same time as this commit, which likely won't happen.  My comment was an effort to avoid a dependency between this repository and code in another repository (ie. the recipe).  Having this kind of dependency means we cannot do integration-style testing in the future easily without later on duplicating that same content here, which means we should just put it here to begin with.

> Even if the variable is empty, the empty value of ${HW_SENSOR_ID} for ExecStart will be translated into an empty argument, that falls into default behavior: 

If the variable is empty you will still have the '-i', right?  And then CLI11 will fail parsing the argument.  Or does systemd do some magic where it passes an empty string, which sh would not normally do?  It seems dangerous to rely on that magic, if it exists.

I have another changes to other repo that are incompatible with current recipe. It's almost impossible to make changes to the individual repo that will still work with current recipes (or requires a significant effort to do so). IMO, it's better to prioritize changes to openbmc meta to such changes. As long as we don't bump version in openbmc meta, individual repo's code will still work.

> If the variable is empty you will still have the '-i', right?  And then CLI11 will fail parsing the argument. 

As per strace output, the invoked command will have "-i" and empty string as params that are legal. I just wondering if CLI11 (in contrast with getopt()) do not allow empty values for the arguments.

I think you're saying that strace shows the parameters should be:
    -i ''
And not just:
    -i

Right?

If there is no parameter for -i then CLI11 gets upset.

$ ./a.out -i   
-i: 1 required TEXT missing
Run with --help for more information.

See https://gist.github.com/ef8ebfcc41d6ae84ad8ec9f52fff50ab for sample.
The strace's output above when HW_SENSOR_ID is not set in env file. The systemd expands arguments differently within ExecStart rather then regular shell expansion.

Just to highlight it:

> execve("/usr/bin/phosphor-hwmon-readd", ["phosphor-hwmon-readd", "-i", "", "-o", "/ahb/apb/bus@1e78a000/i2c-bus@c0"...], 0x7ead0dc0 /* 10 vars */) = 0

This is the execve() straced when service have been started without HW_SENSOR_ID being set in env file.
I'm surprised but ok!
I'm also surprised, but thanks Patrick and Anton for hammering all this out :)
id.empty()?
Done
